answers.text: The essay from which Aims of Education derived its name was delivered as an address in 1916
ideas that are disconnected scraps of information, with no application to real life or culture

qas.question: What was Whitehead's criticism of the use of inert ideas in education?

qas.question: What was Whitehead's criticism of the use of inert ideas in noneducation?

context: Whitehead's most complete work on education is the <a0_0><a3_0><b8_0>1929<b8_0/><a3_0/><a0_0/> book The Aims of Education and Other Essays, which collected <a1_0>numerous essays and addresses<a1_0/> by Whitehead on the subject published <a4_0>between <b9_0>1912 and 1927<b9_0/><a4_0/>. <a5_0><b10_0>The essay from which Aims of Education derived its name was delivered as an address in 1916<b10_0/><a5_0/> when Whitehead was president of the London Branch of the Mathematical Association. In it, he cautioned against the teaching of what he called "<a2_0>inert ideas<a2_0/>" – <a6_0><b11_0>ideas that are disconnected scraps of information<b11_0/>, with no application to real life or culture<a6_0/>. He opined that <a7_0>"<b12_0>education with inert ideas is not only useless: it is, above all things, harmful<b12_0/>."
